stealing, on the 8th of September , two handkerchiefs, value 7 s. , the goods of
Vincent Cross
.

VINCENT CROSS
. I am a linen-draper , and live in Kingsland-road
. These handkerchiefs laid in my window. I missed them, jumped over the counter, and seeing Johnson in the shop, I seized him. Both prisoners were in the shop, but Johnson was nearest the window. I observed him throw the handkerchiefs from him. Clark remained in the shop. They had asked for two black silk laces, and tendered me a 6 d., for which I gave change.

WILLIAM SMITH
. I am a constable. On the 8th of September I took charge of the prisoner. I found the laces in Clark's hand. Neither of them had a farthing about them, although the prosecutor had given Clark 3 d.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
JOHNSON'S Defence. I never had them. He searched me, and not finding them, said I had thrown them over the counter.
CLARK'S Defence. I was not with Johnson.

JOHNSON -
GUILTY .
Transported for Seven Years .

CLARK -
NOT GUILTY .

1271.
HENRY MEAKINS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of September , a lamp-shade, value 2 s. , the goods of
George Woolford
.

GEORGE WOOLFORD
. I am the Blackwall carrier . On the 1st of September, between seven and eight o'clock in the evening, this lamp-shade was tied to the tail of my cart, which was going on between Whitechapel
and Commercial-road
. I had a parcel to deliver; and going round the cart, found the cord cut, and the shade gone, with a prickle which it was in. Jones brought the prisoner to me with it a week after; it was safe in Leadenhall-street. The burner was in the basket with it. I bought it of Messrs. Pellatt and Co.

WILLIAM JONES
. I am a patrol of Bow-street. On the 1st of September I was in Gulston-street, and observed the prisoner coming along with this glass-shade in his hand, done up in brown paper. I asked what he had there. He said a glass bowl, and that it was made for him by one Abrahams, of Wheeler-street, Spitalfields, and he gave 7 s. 6 d. for it. I sent to Abrahams, and in consequence of what he said, I detained the prisoner, and found the prosecutor out a week afterwards. He had not got the prickle.

FREDERICK MOSS
. I am mounter to Messrs. Pellatt and Co. On the 1st of September I sold the lamp, with this shade to Woolford. I know it to be the same.
Prisoner's Defence. I bought it for 7 s. 6 d.
GUILTY .
Transported for Seven Years .
Fourth Jury, Before W. Arabin, Esq.

1272.
WILLIAM HOOPER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of August , three spoons, value 6 s. , the goods of
John Edbury
.

JOHN PARTRIDGE
. I am beadle of Whitechapel. On the 25th of August I was in Rosemary-lane, and saw the prisoner offering three spoons for sale to a Jew. I asked him where he got them from. He said from Mrs. Noon, of Ailiff-street. I took him in custody with them, and found out the prosecutrix.
Cross-examined by MR. WALFORD. Q. He was not sober, was he - A. No.

MARY EDBURY
. I am the wife of
John Edbury
, and live in Little Aliff-street
. The prisoner was recommended to me as a lodger, and was one night in my house. I did not miss the spoons until they were brought to me. They were taken off the back-room table. He was at my house a quarter of an hour before.
Cross-examined. Q. He might have taken them in a joke - A. Very likely.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. She sent me out for rum, and I do not know whether they were put into my pocket or not, for I never saw them.
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Confined Three Months .

1273.
HENRY HOLDER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of July , twenty-four lbs. of soap, value 14 s., the goods of
Joseph Mote
, his master .
MR. BRODRICK conducted the prosecution.

JOSEPH MOTE
. I am a soap manufacturer , and live in Hill-street, Finsbury
. The prisoner was my confidential clerk for three years. After soap is manufactured, it is put into the store-room; in consequence of suspicion, I employed two officers to watch: he occupied two rooms in my house. On the 30th of July, I ascertained the quantity of soap in the store-room. I reckoned 38 cakes to a cwt., and by that calculation, there were 2 l cwt.; I ordered him to deliver 6 1/4 cwt. to a customer; only a labourer, myself, and him had access to the soap. The labourers were under his controul. The soap was moist on the evening of the 29th - it was then all correct; he was to deliver out the 6 1/4 cwt. On the 30th, the officers took him into custody; on that day I went with them into his room; I found eight cakes of soap on the floor, between the bed and wall; it was moist, similar to the pile; I went to the store-room, and found eight cakes deficient.

Cross-examined by MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. When had the pile been manufactured - A. I cannot exactly say; I think not a fortnight or three weeks - there might be two or three tons weight made. I sold Mr. Freeman 56 lbs. of each; the prisoner said it was the residue of a 1/4 of cwt. he had bought of Freeman; he bought soap of me occasionally; there was a closet in his room, where he might have hid it. I had Freeman apprehended.
MR. BRODRICK. Q. He was charged with receiving the soap - A. Yes; soap in small quantities will get dry in a quarter of an hour.

JOSEPH HANDLEY
. I was directed to watch the prisoner and took him in charge on Wednesday, the 30th of July; and told him under what circumstances I came, and asked him if I should find any soap there? He said I should; he has two rooms over the warehouse. He said, he bought the soap of Freeman; I found eleven cakes piled together, between the bed and wall - the bed was two feet from the wall - it resembled the pile in size, appearance, and moisture.

Prisoner's Defence. They went to inquire if I had it of Freeman; I said, I had the soap, it was part of a 1/4 of cwt. which I bought the week preceding of Freeman; I was detained while the prosecutor went to inquire at Freeman's.

JOSEPH MOTE
. I had not sold soap to him, since he lived on the premises, but think two years ago he bought a little.

FREEMAN. I am a tallow-chandler, and live in Wilson-street, Finsbury. On the 23d of July, I bought 1/4 a cwt. of soap of Mote; and on the 25th, sold the prisoner a 1/4 of cwt. of it. I believe the soap to be part of the same.

MR. BRODRICK. Q. He was servant to a soap-maker - A. Yes, I have sold him several 1/4 cwts.; I charged him 2 s. more on a cwt. than I gave; I do not sell soap for less than I give. I remember offering a cwt. at 1 s. less, when I wanted money to make up a bill. I will not swear that I have not sold some to Cook, of Union-street. I never sold soap to a man named Cook.
NOT GUILTY .

1275.
JOHN FEARBY
and
JOSEPH WOOD
were indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of September , five sovereigns; one 10 l., and one 5 l., Bank notes , the property of
Thomas Herrington
.

THOMAS HERRINGTON
. I am a farmer's bailiff . I left my situation in Hertfordshire, a week ago last Monday; and on Friday, between nine and ten o'clock in the morning, I was going to Smithfield market; the prisoner Wood overtook me, and asked me if I was going to the market; I said, I was; he said he was going there too, and asked which was the best market-day; I said, I rather thought Monday; he said, he was come to town on business, and thought he would stop to see Monday's market; we walked nearly through the market, he asked me to take a pint of beer; I said, with all my heart, I was going to follow him into the house, but he said, No, we will sit down outside; he went in and fetched a pint of beer, we sat down and drank it. I said, I would be a pint, but we had no more; he carried the pot in and paid for it; he then said, we would walk on further, if I had no objection, and then have another pint; we went through the market, then walked away till we came into the New Road
- he asked me to go in there and have a pint - I said Yes, with all my heart - and so we went in. A young man was there, who was afterwards with the prisoners. Fearby came in while we sat there. They seemed all strangers to each other. Fearby said he was a countryman, and had come to settle some business of money that had been owing for sixteen months - that he had applied to a gentleman, who he mentioned, who got 550 l. for him, and 550 l. for his brother - and that his brother was very infortunate in getting into a coach, he fell down and put his instep out. Wood said there was no such a word as infortunate, and wanted to lay a wager about it - they laid a pot of beer - Fearby paid for it, and then said we all three looked like poor men, and could not shew 10 l. a-piece. I said I had not 10 l. with me, but I expected some up from home by that day's post, and could produce it in a short time. Fearby then wanted to lay 3 l. to 1 l. that we did not each produce a 10 l. note by one o'clock. Wood and the young man pulled out their 10 l. each; and the young man walked with me up to Tottenham-court-road, where my parcel was coming, but the letter had not come. We left the prisoners at the public-house. Fearby then said he would give me till two o'clock - I said I would stand to the wager. The young man said he wanted to go into Tottenham-court-road to get change for some money, and would go with me; the prisoners said they would go too; we all four of us went; and they went into an inn while I went for my letter - it was not come - I asked my friend to lend me 20 l., which he did. We then went back to the inn, and shewed Fearby our 10 l. each, all three of us; then he said he would lay another 1 l. that we could not shew another 10 l. I then shewed him another 10 l.; he then gave into the hands of Wood a 5 l. note, as he said they then wanted to go and see the balloon go off - and so did I. They got a coach, and we all went in it; the young man looked out of the coach, and said he knew of a convenient place where we could have refreshment. Fearby had said before that he would treat us with a bottle of wine, and change the 5 l. note; so we went to the inn. Wood and the young man asked if they might go up to a private room - the landlord said we might have the parlour - and we went into the parlour. Wood called for a pot of ale and a glass of shrub and water - and the young man said he would go and order some steaks, and while they were cooking we could have a game at cards. They asked me to play - I said No. Fearby and the young man played three or four games at all-fours; the young man had four chalks out of five. Fearby dealt the last deal, and begged to be excused to go out for a moment after he had dealt his cards, and wished us not to look at them. The young man took up his hand of cards, looked at them, and said it was such a good hand, he was sure to beat. Wood said

"Let us lay him a wager about the game;" so when Fearby came in, the young man said he would lay him a wager - oh, he said, he would lay him any thing - that he would beat either 10 l. or 20 l. a-piece if he liked; then Fearby said he would lay 60 l. to our 20 l. each; he got up and put his money in a hat on another table - the others put down theirs, and wished me to put down mine - so I did, into the hat with the others; they then wanted me to play the hand for him, and said play how I would I was sure to win; I said I would not, three or four times - but they very much persuaded me, saying I could not lose - and so I played and lost - then Fearby said he had won the game, and got up and took the hat. Wood beckoned me out of the door - I went; and he said he should be back in ten minutes or a quarter of an hour, if I could step with him; and when I returned into the room they were all gone. I went to Hatton-garden, and they were taken up that evening.
Cross-examined by MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. You understand all-fours, don't you - A. No; very little; but they said play how I would, I was sure to win.
Q. You laid your money into the hat, to be won or lost as the game should go - A. Yes; I lost the game.
NOT GUILTY .

1276.
MARY EDWARDS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of August , two half-crowns, the monies of
John Steins
, from his person .

JOHN STEINS
. I am a journeyman tailor . On the 4th of August, between three and four o'clock in the afternoon, I was walking in the Hampstead-road
; the prisoner came up and asked me for some halfpence - she had two little girls with her. She followed me a long while, and said they had nothing to eat - and I said I had no halfpence. I put my hand into my pocket, pulled out my money - I had some silver and copper together; the prisoner snatched two half-crowns out of my hand and ran off. I followed and overtook her in five minutes, without losing sight of her; she had not ran far; I took one half-crown from her hand, but could not find the other. I did not see her searched, but the other was found upon her - I was sober - I knew nothing of her before.

CHARLES COUSINS
. I am an officer. I searched the prisoner, and found the half-crown in her hand. She said he gave it her.
Prisoner's Defence. I never said any such thing.
GUILTY . Aged 15.

Strongly Recommended to Mercy. -
Judgment Respited .

1277.
HENRY GRANT
and
THOMAS JONES
were indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of August , three live tame fowls, price 2 s. , the property of
William King
.
The prosecutor being unable to swear to the fowls, the prisoners were
ACQUITTED .

1278.
JOHN COX
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2d of September , a glass domb, value 6 s. the goods of
James Smeehart
.

HORATIO TAYLOR
. I am shopman to Mr.
James Smeehurst
, lamp-manufacturer , New Bond-street
. The prisoner was in his service.

THOMAS CLEMENTS
. I am an officer. On the 2d of September, a little past nine o'clock at night, I was in Bond-street, and saw the prisoner carrying a basket. I stopped him, and asked what he had got. After some hesitation, he said a glass domb; that he was going to do a job for himself with it; on our way to the office, he said he would tell me the truth; that he worked for Mr. Smeethart, in Bond-street, and took the domb to force a few plants in his garden.

HORATIO TAYLOR
. I cannot swear to the domb - we have so many we could not miss it.
Cross-examined by MR. ALLEY. Q. How many men have you - A. Five; he was eleven years with us, and was never allowed to take things off the premises.
NOT GUILTY .

1279.
ANN PENNY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of August , a child's pincloth, value 15 d. , the goods of
Elizabeth Holroyd
.

ELIZABETH HOLROYD
. I live in Bluegate-fields
. I lost a child's pinafore. On the 29th of August, I put it in the yard to dry, between two and three o'clock in the day. I missed it about six, and have never found it since.

ELIZA SIMPSON
. I was sitting at work opposite the prosecutrix's house, and saw the prisoner take the pinafore off the line, and come out with it - she rolled it up - I heard of the robbery afterwards, and told what I knew.

Prisoner's Defence. I went into this house at five o'clock, and stopped till eight, when a person came and told me what I was charged with. I immediately went to the prosecutrix; she fell upon me and tore my bonnet off my head - I told her to send for an officer - she sent to my husband, and said, if he would give her 5 l., she would make it up, and he gave her 1 l. The officer saw her strike me.

ELIZABETH HOLROYD
. I never lifted my hand against her, or spoke to her husband about anything of the kind.

STEPHEN CADMAN
. I am an officer - I did not see her strike her, or ever hear that she had.
NOT GUILTY .

1280.
THOMAS WICKS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of August , a watch, value 30 s., the goods of
Thomas Rigby
, from his person .

THOMAS RIGBY
. I live in the New-road, St. George's. On the 17th of August, about half-past nine o'clock, I was in Whitechapel-road
; I had a child in my arms, and my housekeeper by my side. I passed a doctor's shop, at the corner of North-street
- the prisoner gave me a shove and turned me right round - there was a gas-light at the corner, and at the doctor's shop also - he came from behind, and shoved me, turned me right round, and snatched my watch from my fob, and ran up North-street - I pursued, calling out Stop thief! he was not taken then - I saw him in custody four days after, and cannot swear to him, as I only saw his back.
Cross-examined by MR. ALLEY. Q. Did you recover your watch - A. Yes; it was sent to me a week or ten days after.

SARAH RIGBY
. I was in company with Mrs. Rigby, walking on his left side - he was carrying the child. I noticed a man following us, and looked round several times, thinking he knew us - he was alone. At the corner of North-street, he came behind us and gave Mr. Rigby a shove on the left shoulder, I did not see him snatch the watch - he ran down North-street; an alarm was given. Mr. Rigby ran after him - I took the child from him, and another person came behind and threw him down - I saw the prisoner in custody on the 22d - there was a gas light from the shop, and one from the corner - I believe him to be the man, and am sure that he is.
Cross-examined. Q. You never knew him before - A. No; I never fixed on any other - I was coming out of a friend's house in North-street, and Mr. Rigby said,
"This looks like the man who tripped me up." I said,
"It is not him, for he was a great deal taller." I described him to the officers, and when I saw the prisoner, I was certain of him.

GEORGE ELLIS
. I am an officer. Mr. and Mrs. Rigby gave me a description of the men on the Monday after the robbery, and in consequence of the woman's description, I apprehended the prisoner on the Wednesday following. I knew him before. The woman never hesitated about him.
GUILTY . Aged 20.
Transported for Seven Years .

1281.
PATRICK COLLINS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of June , a waistcoat, value 6 s. , the goods of
William Howes
.

WILLIAM HOWES
. I am a pawnbroker , and live in High-street, St. Giles's
. On the 27th of June I lost a waistcoat from my door post, just about eight o'clock in the morning.

CHARLES PERRY
. I am a pawnbroker, and live in Museum-street, about twenty minutes past nine o'clock, the prisoner pawned this waistcoat for 2 s. - he came again about one o'clock, for another shilling on it, and I detained him. I am sure he pawned it.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did you know him before - A. No.

WILLIAM HOWES
. I have no mark on them, but know them to be mine.
NOT GUILTY .

1282.
ABBY SULLIVAN
and
ELLEN DONOVAN
were indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of September , five yards of printed cotton, value 10 s. , the goods of
Edward Price
.

SARAH PRICE
. I am a fishmonger, and live in Brill-row, Somers-town
. On the 11th of September, between four and five o'clock in the afternoon, the prisoners came in and had three pennyworth of oysters. Sullivan came first, and said, wait until my sister comes; and then Donovan came in, and they eat the oysters between them, and left the shop together. They returned in a quarter of an hour, and when they were gone I missed a gown-piece of five yards and a quarter of printed cotton out of a band-box on the counter. I had not left the shop. They were behind me, and so was the cotton. They examined the gown whilst they were in the shop, and said they liked it very much. I pursued them directly. I had put it in the box again. Nobody but them were there till I missed it.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Another woman was in the shop - A. No; one came in after they were gone, and asked to see it. I looked, and it was gone. I had drank three glasses of gin and part of a pot of beer, but knew what I was about, and drank with the prisoners in the shop. When they were taken, they acknowledged to taking it and pawning it. They said for God's sake be merciful to us - we will never do such a thing again - we did it out of a lark, and said they had torn the duplicate up.

W - B - TOMLINSON. I am a pawnbroker in of Lower Wilmot-street, Brunswick-square. On the 11th of September, between five and six o'clock in the evening, the prisoners came and pawned this cotton. They said they gave 2 s. 6 d. for it. Price was very much in liquor.
Cross-examined. Q. I believe many people buy goods at tally-shops and pawn them - A. Yes.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

WILLIAM CLARK
. I am a beadle. The prosecutrix pointed the prisoners out to me in Newton-street. I took Sullivan to the watch-house; the other followed. I locked them both up. They said they had pawned the gown, and had torn up the duplicate.
SULLIVAN'S Defence. I was passing her door. She called me in, and asked for drink. We drank together, and I lent her 1 s.
DONOVAN'S Defence. We had beer and gin together, and we had some oysters of her. She lent Sullivan the gown to pawn till the morning, when she would give her the money.
SULLIVAN - GUILTY.
DONOVAN - GUILTY.

Recommended to Mercy by the Jury . -
Confined 2 Months .
FIFTEENTH DAY. FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 25.
Middlesex Cases, Fourth Jury, Before W. Arabin, Esq.

1283.
CHARLES RANDALL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of September , one ornamental hair front, value 5 s. , the goods of
Sarah Spedding
.
The Prisoner pleaded
GUILTY .
Fined One Shilling and Discharged.

1284.
WILLIAM LONG
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of August , a watch, value 30 s., the goods of
Samuel Warburton Mitchell
, from the person of
James Alexander Mitchell
.

JAMES ALEXANDER MITCHELL
. I am the son of Samuel Warburton > Mitchell. On the 14th of August, between eight and nine o'clock in the evening, I was going along Hackney-road
. The prisoner came up, and snatched my watch out of my fob, and ran down Weymouth-terrace. I gave an alarm, and he was stopped before I lost sight of him. I am sure he is the man. The watch was picked up on the spot where he was taken, near the Duke of Wellington, public-house.
Cross-examined by MR. ALLEY. Q. What sort of a night was it - A. Not particularly light; there was nobody else about - he ran about a hundred yards.

MARIA MITCHELL
. I was with my brother. A man came from the road and snatched his watch - the case immediately dropped - I picked it up. The prisoner was stopped - but I cannot speak to him.

THOMAS FIELD
. I keep the Duke of Wellington, public-house. An alarm was given. I ran out, and next morning I found the watch over Mr. Lambeth's wall, under which he was stopped.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

GEORGE SMITH
. I am an officer, and received him in charge.
Prisoner's Defence. I solemnly declare my innocence. I was going to see my aunt at Haggerston. I heard an alarm, and pursued the thief in the fields, fell down, and was taken.
GUILTY . Aged 20.
Transported for Life .

1285.
ELLEN ARNOLD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of July , two half-crowns, fourteen shillings, and four sixpences, the monies of
Alexander Smith
, her master .

EMILY BARNES
. I am bar-maid to Mr.
Alexander Smith
, a publican . On the 13th of July, this bag was in the till, and contained about 28 s. all in silver, I saw it safe between three and four o'clock; I found the bag still there and 18 d. left in it. The prisoner was servant in the house; we charged her with taking it, she denied it; an officer was called, she was searched, but nothing found. After that, I remembered seeing her with a little box the day before, and asked her to produce it. She at last produced it out of a sack of sawdust which was kept in the kitchen, and begged of me to forgive her, and at the same time gave me 21 s., saying she had not taken a sixpence more.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. You said if she confessed, you would not hurt her - A. It was said so at first, that if she would give up the money, Mr. Smith would do nothing.

THOMAS HARRISON
. I am an officer. I was in the parlour at the time Smith complained of money being taken. I searched the prisoner, but found nothing. Smith said if she gave up the money, he would forgive her, but as she did not do so, the bar-maid said she had a box; she was asked about it, and said she had given it to a young girl; the girl denied it; she fell down and said,
"What shall I do?" I said, tell where the property is, and your master will forgive you. She said, it was in the sawdust box, and produced it from there.
GUILTY . Aged 14.
Fined One Shilling and Discharged.

1286.
EDWARD HOGAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3d of August , a handkerchief, value 2 s., the goods of
William Sandford
, from his person .

WILLIAM SANDFORD
. I am a journeyman silversmith , and live in Monkwell-street. On the 3d of August, about ten o'clock at night, I was passing along Bloomsbury
, and heard the cry of Stop thief! I saw somebody running along the other side of the way; Riley brought the prisoner up to me, and said, he had picked my pocket; I then felt, and missed my handkerchief. Riley produced it.

PHILIP RILEY
. I am a patrol of Bloomsbury. About ten o'clock at night, I saw the prisoner and two others at the corner of George-street, I watched them; the prosecutor and a female went by - they both followed behind; the prisoner stopped down, and took the handkerchief out of his pocket, turned round and ran against me; I seized him, and said,
"Ned, this won't do;" he immediately dropped it, and I picked it up, and called to the people to stop the prosecutor.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. He laid hold of me, and said I stole the handkerchief - he found it on the ground.
GUILTY . Aged 15.
Transported for Life ,

1287.
ELEANOR COLLINS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of September , a watch, value 20 s., the goods of
James Lampard
, from his person .

JAMES LAMPARD
. I am a hair-dresser . On the 8th of September, about ten o'clock in the morning, I went to a public-house, in Golden-lane
; I was a little fresh - I had got up about seven o'clock; the prisoner was at the public-house with her mother and two other women. I treated them, and when they were gone, I missed my watch which was safe when I went into their company - they all sat by me at times - I found it in pawn. I never lost my senses, and knew who was with me.

DANIEL POPE
. I am a pawnbroker in Whitecross-street. The prisoner pawned the watch with me. I am certain of her.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I never pawned it or stole it - the person who did it has been to me in the prison.
NOT GUILTY .

1288.
CHARLOTTE ANN ALVEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of September , from the person of
John Holmes
, seven sovereigns, and one Bank note , his property.

JOHN HOLMES
. I am a sailor . On the night of the 6th of September. I met the prisoner at the Black Horse, public-house, Rosemary-lane
; she asked me to have something to drink - I gave her some rum and water, and stopped there for half an hour; I had a 5 l. note in my waistcoat pocket, and seven sovereigns in my side pocket. I do not know what time it was - I was drunk, but recollect what passed - she put her hand into my pocket, and took seven sovereigns - I felt her do it, and she took the 5 l. note from my waistcoat pocket; we were then in the street, we had gone outside the door - I took the 5 l. note out of her mouth - she ran away, I did not follow her; but in the morning, I found her drinking, and gave her in charge. I gave the note to the officer, and have not found the sovereigns.

THOMAS HARRISON
. I am an officer. I was going out on the 7th of September; and at the watch-house, I found the prosecutor, the prisoner, and two more - he gave charge of her for robbing him of seven sovereigns, and a 5 l. note, and shewed me the note, saying he took it from her mouth; he was a little fresh then; I asked her what she did with the sovereigns; she said she did not take them; I asked her what she did with the note - she gave no answer.

Prisoner's Defence. I met him about half past one o'clock at night; he said, he wanted a girl who lived in St. Catherine's. I said, perhaps I might know her - I went to look for her - he had 5 s. or 6 s. worth of rum and water, and was very much in liquor.
GUILTY . Aged 29.
Transported for Seven Years .
Before Mr. Recorder.

1289.
LAWRENCE CLEAREY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of July , thirty-nine sovereigns, the monies of
Thomas Faby
, from his person .
MR. WALFORD conducted the prosecution.

THOMAS FABY
. I live in Brewer's-court, Bedfordbury; the prisoner lodged in my house. On the 7th of July, about half-past eleven o'clock, I received thirty-nine sovereigns fourteen shillings and eleven-pence, at the Bank - Mary Knaven was with me. After receiving my money it rained, and we went into the Mansion-house, public-house, and had a pot of ale; I was in her company about two hours and a half, and parted with her in Fleet-street. I had drank three glasses of liquor and part of a pot of ale; when I parted from her, she asked if my money was safe, I felt and found it so. I went home about three o'clock, and went to bed in one of my lodger's rooms, it was the prisoner's room. I cannot say whether my money was then safe, I continued in bed from three to five o'clock; I had carried my money loose in my trowsers pocket; the last time I felt, it was in Fleet-street. I met nobody in the way home, nor did I stay anywhere that I recollect. I awoke at five o'clock, and my money was gone; I saw the prisoner at eleven that night, and saw him again next day, and he shewed me eleven sovereigns in a pocket book; I asked how he came by them, he said he had them from a young woman who he kept company with, and who had taken them from a foreigner overnight.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERCAST. Q. Do not youknow that he was acquainted with a young woman - A. He knew a servant at Newton's hotel, St. Martin's-street, which is a house for the reception of foreigners; he said the woman had robbed the foreigner of it - I suspected that it was mine. I am sure it was safe when I left Knaven; I did not charge her with taking it. She was examined at Guildhall, on the 10th or 11th of July, for being in company with me; I could not then recollect when I had the money; it came to my memory next evening; she was two days in custody. I called at Knaven's house; I was not drunk when I went there - I carried her child home; she then came on to Fleet-street with me; I fell down on her stairs, as my foot slipped. I took the prisoner up three weeks after, he had not absconded, but lodged with me all the time. I never consulted a fortune-teller about it.

MR. WALFORD. Q. You fell down at Knaven's house - A. Yes; my money was safe after that. I went to her house to ask about it, that occasioned words between me and her husband. I was taken before the Magistrate, and she was brought up by the Magistrate's desire.

MARY KNAVEN
. I am the wife of
John Knaven
- my husband is the prosecutor's first cousin; he is a bricklayer. I went to the Bank with him - he was sober. He received a great many sovereigns at the Bank, and put them into his breeches pocket; this was past twelve o'clock. He went to a public-house with me, and then went to my house; he drank some liquor, in Bow-lane; he had a pot of ale at a public-house, also three half quarterns of rum, and a quartern of gin - he was tipsy. I went as far as St. Paul's with him, and said,
"Have you got your money safe?"
"Oh! Yes," said he, slipping his hand in his pocket, and I heard his money jingle. I parted with him at St. Paul's. I live in Great Trinity-lane - he went home with me before I parted with him.

Cross-examined. Q. How long were you in custody - A. He came in the afternoon; the constable took me - I was discharged the same day. He told the Magistrate he rather thought I had got it; he had come to my house that night, and said he was sure I had his money, and told the Magistrate so.

MARGARET FABY
. I am the wife of the prosecutor. The prisoner lodged with us. On the morning of the robbery he wanted to borrow 2 s. 6 d. of me, to go to a raffle at night; I did not lend it him, and he got me to send my girl to pawn a pair of breeches, for 2 s. 6 d.; she went and brought me the half-crown, between nine and ten o'clock in the morning, and he never came to me for it. My husband came home after three o'clock, and went up and slept in the prisoner's room, till five o'clock. He came into the house while my husband was up stairs; I do not know whether he went up, for I went out, leaving him there. A woman, who lived with the prisoner, as his wife (but not in our house) was in the house at the time.

COURT. Q. I suppose she went into the prisoner's room whenever she came to the house - A. Yes; she and the prisoner had plenty of opportunities of going there - she was in the house between three and five o'clock, and the prisoner was there with her. He owed me 1 l. 15 s. 4 d. for rent, and paid me next morning, and said he got the money from a young woman who robbed a foreigner of it. He shewed me ten or eleven sovereigns in a pocket-book, and said he was to get 20 l. as a fortune with the young woman who he married; he married her two or three days after, and told me he was married by licence.

Cross-examined. Q. When did you see the prisoner at the house - A. About a quarter after three o'clock; I was sitting in my room, and told him my husband had come home. The woman was in my room at the time, both before and after the prisoner came in. The prisoner's room is on the second floor; I went out, leaving them together - I was not absent a quarter of an hour.

MR. WALFORD. Q. How long after your husband went to bed did the woman come in - A. She was in the house a quarter of an hour - her name is
Mary Riley
- she saw my husband come in and go up stairs. She went up and down before Clearey came in.

JAMES BROWN
. I lodge in the house. On this morning the prisoner wanted me to lend him 2 s. 6 d. to go to a raffle - I gave him leave to pawn my breeches for 2 s. 6 d., as I had no money. I saw him again between seven and eight o'clock in the evening at a wine vaults - he changed a sovereign, and paid me. I asked how he got it - he said he got it of his wife.

JOHN DUFFY
, I am a labourer, and live in Oxford Buildings. On the 7th of July I saw the prisoner at a raffle in Broad-street, Carnaby-market, and saw him with some sovereigns; he said he had plenty of money, and shewed me a white stocking, and strewed them all over the table; he said he got them by hard labour.
Cross-examined. Q. This was a long time ago - A. I cannot tell - it was not at a raffle - I heard of a raffle that evening.

MARY BAILEY
. I keep the Black Horse, public-house, Vine-street, Chandos-street; the prisoner came to my house one day the beginning of July with a woman, and had a glass of rum and water, about ten o'clock in the morning; I changed a sovereign for him - and then changed another for him.

THOMAS GAYNARD
. Shortly after I heard of this robbery the prisoner told me he had got a great deal of money from a young woman, who took it from a foreigner. I saw him give a man eleven sovereigns.
Cross-examined. Q. Where was this - A. At Faby's house. The man said he gave him eleven sovereigns; I did not see him with them myself.

THOMAS BOYLE
. The prisoner told me he had some sovereigns of a woman who robbed a foreigner of them. I saw him change one at a public-house.

ANTHONY M'KEAL
. I saw the prisoner with eleven sovereigns at Faby's house on the Saturday after the robbery; he said he got them from a sweetheart of his - that he went to borrow two shillings of her to go to a raffle, and she gave them to him; and he rather thought she got them from a foreigner.

JOSEPH HOLYLAND
. I am an officer. I searched the prisoner's lodging in Faby's house, and found nineteen sovereigns in a box, wrapped in a piece of rag. There were no men's clothes there - only ribbons and caps. A woman who called herself his wife gave us the key, and was present at the search.

THOMAS FABY
. I saw the box searched - it belonged to his wife; he married her three days after the robbery. He kept his clothes in that box.

Prisoner's Defence. I did not leave work till half past five o'clock that afternoon, then came home. Faby said her husband was drunk, and told me to go to watch for him - I went and staid till eight o'clock, then returned, and found neither of them at home; they were gone to Knaven's house; he said she had the money. I never denied having this money.

THOMAS BOYLE
re-examined. I came home about five o'clock - I do not know where the prisoner was then - he went to watch in Faby's place; I went into the room, and Faby was dressing himself.

MICHAEL NEEREY
. I knew the prisoner in Ireland and in England. I saw him with forty-seven sovereigns at the time Faby was robbed; he counted them twice at the raffle, and said he found them between Whitcomb-street and the Haymarket.
MR. WALFORD. Q. Are you sure it was on the day of the raffle - A. Yes; on the day before; it was at the Fortune of War, East-street.
GUILTY . Aged 27.
Transported for Life .

1290.
ANN BURNS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of June , two crowns, one half-crown, five shillings, and five sixpences, the monies of
Margaret Chappell
, widow , from her person .

MARGARET CHAPPELL
. I live in George-yard, Whitechapel. On the 25th of June, about half-past four o'clock in the afternoon, the prisoner came and asked me to walk with her; we went to a wine vaults, and had a quartern of rum - she wanted me to buy the duplicate of a blanket, but I refused - she said, if she had 1 s. 6 d. she would take it out of pawn. I went home for my money, and put a pound in my bosom, which I had to go to market with. It was two crowns, a half-crown, and silver. I lent her 18 d. and then called for another quartern of rum; I found my head heavy, and fell asleep. A young man awoke me, I found my money was gone; I caught her over the way at another wine vaults, and said,

"Where is my money, that you took out of my bosom;" she said, if I would go to her sister, she would make it all right. I caught hold of her hand, and a half-crown and 1 s. 6 d. fell from it on the ground.
Prisoner. Q. Were you not tried here - A. Never; I was at Hick's-hall for an assault.

JAMES CATHERWOOD
. I went into the wine vaults to get some beer, the prosecutrix was asleep. I saw the prisoner with her arm round the prosecutrix's neck, and her hand at her bosom; she pushed the corner of her handkerchief out; I suspected she was robbing her; she untied the corner of the handkerchief. I told the landlady of it, and she awoke the prosecutrix. The prisoner was crossing the road at the time the prosecutor went after her - I did not say anything to her. I am a horse dealer, and live in George-yard, Whitechapel.

JOHN SEABROOK
. I was attending at the opposite wine vaults. The prisoner came in, and asked me to take care of 15 s. for her; I have known her a long time - she had scarcely put it down before the prosecutrix followed her, and seized her by the collar; she directly said,
"If you will go to my sister's, I will make it all right with you;" they went out together. She has put money in my care before.

FRANCIS FREEMAN
. On the 25th of June, the prosecutrix brought the prisoner to the office. She was discharged at the second examination, as we did not know the money was left with Seabrook. I found two sixpences on her.

Prisoner's Defence. I received 30 s. on the 24th, I was coming home, and met the prosecutrix, and went to drink with her; she asked me to lend her some money, as she had lost a good deal by mackarel. I said, I had none to lend her - we drank two or three hours. I went to leave my money with this young man; she came over and said, I had robbed her, and took 2 s. 6 d. out of my hand.

JOHN SEABROOK
. The prisoner said nothing at my house about the prosecutrix having no money.
GUILTY . Aged 22.
Fined One Shilling and Discharged.

1291.
GEORGE WALDUCK
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3d of June , five jugs, value 5 s.; six dishes, value 3 s.; two chamber pots, value 18 d.; twelve cups, value 18 d.; an ewer, value 18 d., and a basin, value 10 d. , the goods of
Sarah Goodman
.

SARAH GOODMAN
. I live in Walbrook-place, Hoxton
. I employed men to hawk earthenware . The prisoner came to live with me on the 21st of May. On the 3d of June I sent him out with a basket of things - he never returned; he had given me no notice. There were altogether twenty-six shillings worth,

WILLIAM CONSTANTINE
. I apprehended the prisoner at Pickford's wharf, in the City-road. On the 14th of July, the prosecutrix fetched me to take him; I told him the charge; he said he would go and work it out.
NOT GUILTY .

1292.
JOSEPH HOPE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of September , a seal, value 30 s.; a watch key, value 15 s., and a ring, value 1 s., the goods of
Richard Price
, from his person .

RICHARD PRICE
. I keep the Magpie and Stump, public-house, in the New-road. St. George's in the East
. On the 6th of September, between five and six o'clock in the afternoon, I was in my bar - the prisoner came and asked for a glass of gin - he went into the tap-room; I took it to him; he said,

"This won't do for me, I want my gin in a measure;" I put it into a measure, and gave it to him, and asked him for the money - he gave me 1 1/2 d.; I said I wanted 2 d.; he said he should give me no more; I insisted on having 2 d., and said I should turn him out if he did not pay me. He was going to sit down; I took and carried him to the outside door; he immediately made a short turn, and snatched at my watch; the ring broke, and he set off with the seal, and I followed and secured him about twenty yards off. He scuffled a good deal - the seal was found just by; he had thrown it into the road while I pursued him.

JOHN CHURCHILL
. I am servant to Mr. Price. I picked up the seal three minutes after he was secured; it was eight or ten yards from the door.
(Seal produced and sworn to.)

FRANCIS JACKSON
. I am a constable. I found the prisoner struggling with Price - he said he was surgeon of a frigate.
The prisoner in a written Defence, stated that he was inebriated,and in the scuffle he happened to catch hold of the watch, and the ribbon broke; but denied any felonious intention.
NOT GUILTY .

1293.
ANN HALL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 31st of August , a watch, value 2 l.; a watch key, value 3 s.; a seal, value 6 s.; a chain, value 6 d.; a pocket-book, value 6 d., and two handkerchiefs, value 1 s. , the goods of
Robert Smeaton
.

ROBERT SMEATON
. I belong to the Revenue service . On the 30th of August, about eleven o'clock at night, I went into a court in Cable-street
, for a necessary purpose, and the prisoner came up the court, and invited me into her room in the same court - another woman came for 2 s. for the use of the room - I stopped till four o'clock next morning. The room door was locked - my watch was under the bolster, and my trowsers and property also. I missed my watch, and accused her of taking it - she denied it. I was perfectly sober.

FRANCIS JACKSON
. I am a constable. On Sunday morning, the 31st of August between four and five o'clock, the watchman brought the prisoner to the watch-house - she had left the house. I went to the room between eleven and twelve o'clock, and found the handkerchief, with carrots and turnips tied up in it. I found the prisoner in bed there, with a man she lives with; she was much intoxicated, and the prosecutor was rather fresh. She said she gave the watch to another girl, or that another girl had it. There is no lock to the door.

Prisoner's Defence. I met him very drunk; he sent me out for drink, and when I came back he was asleep, and the door open. I awoke him, and he drank most of the liquor. Another woman came up, and drank with him.

ROBERT SMEATON
. There was no liquor in the room. I thought she locked the door.
NOT GUILTY .

1294.
JOHN WILLIAMS
and
WILLIAM HIGGS
were indicted, for
stealing, on the 26th of August , a waistcoat, value 2 s., and a piece of cloth, value 1 s., the goods of
William Crow
, from his person .

WILLIAM CROW
. At the time of the robbery, I lived at Ashford, near Staines. On the 26th of August, about eleven o'clock at night, I was coming from Hounslow
to Ashford
, I was not intoxicated - I had a bundle, containing a waistcoat and an apron. There were four young men on the road in liquor; they snatched my bundle from me; the prisoners are two of them; they snatched the bundle out of my hand. I knew two of them before, but not the prisoners - Page, who I knew, snatched it and gave it to Williams, he delivered it up to me, and Page snatched it from me again; I got the waistcoat back the same night It might be a joke.
NOT GUILTY .

1295.
RICHARD LOVELL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of September , one shilling, one sixpence, and five penny pieces, the monies of
Maria Gilham
, from her person .

MARIA GILHAM
. I am an unfortunate girl . I lived in Twine-court, Shadwell
. Last Friday fortnight, about half-past eight o'clock at night, the prisoner came into my room - I had seen him in the street before - I refused to give him my company - he insisted on it, and put the light out, and pushed me on the bed - while I was on the bed, he accused me of stealing a five shilling piece from him. I denied it - he then said, I had stolen half-a-crown. I said, I had not got one - he turned up the bed, and said he knew where the money was, and took a shilling, a sixpence and five penny pieces from under the bed; he said, it was part of his money. I knew him before: he ill used me, and I charged him with an assault.
NOT GUILTY .

1296.
SOPHIA FOX
was indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of September , a pair of boots, value 6 s. , the goods of
Joseph Hodges
.

JOSEPH HODGES
. I am a shoemaker , and live in Mary-le-bone-lane
. On the 11th of September, about half-past six o'clock in the evening, these boots were stolen. I went out at ten minutes after six, and they were safe - I returned and found the prisoner in custody with them.

JOHN CHUMLEY
. I live opposite to Hodges. About half-past six o'clock in the evening, I saw the prisoner go up to the prosecutor's door, and take these goods down, and walk away with them; I ran over and called Mrs. Hodges, who pursued, and took her with them.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

SARAH HODGES
. I followed her and took them from her.
GUILTY .
Fined One Shilling and Discharged.

1297.
CHARLES FULLER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of July , three hundred nails, value 18 d. , the goods of
Mark Cohen
.

MARK COHEN
. I am a builder , and live in John-street, Bedford-square. On the 10th of July, about eight o'clock in the morning, I filled a box with six hundred nails, and left them in care of a boy, while I was sent for to breakfast; I returned in half an hour, and missed half of them. The prisoner was employed as a plaisterer at some buildings in the neighbourhood - he was taken four or five days after, and brought to me - my boy is not here.
NOT GUILTY .

1298.
ROBERT GOODISON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of September , five loaves of bread, value 3 s. 6 d. , the goods of
James Vyse
.

JAMES VYSE
. I am a baker . On the 11th of September I sent the prisoner out with sixty-four loaves and a half of bread to serve the customers with. He brought ten and a half home, and booked all the rest to customers, but has not accounted to me for the money.
NOT GUILTY .

1299.
RICHARD PHILLIPS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of September , four books, value 10 s. , the goods of
William Bowles
.

WILLIAM BOWLES
, JUN. I am the son of
William Bowles
, a bookseller , and live in the New-road, Somers-town
. These books were on a board in front of the shop. I saw the prisoner at the board, and in consequence of what I heard, I went and overtook him with four books which are my father's. He pleaded distress.

MARY RICE
. I saw him go from this shop with something, and told Bowles, who found the books on him.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY .
Fined One Shilling and Discharged.

1300.
JOHN QUIN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of September , a handkerchief, value 5 s. , the goods of
Michael Wallis
.

SOPHIA VICKERS
. I have a house in Glasshouse-fields
; Michael Wallis rents a room in it. The prisoner came to the door, and asked for Wallis. I said,

"He is not within" This handkerchief laid on the table, in the same room. I went down into the cellar while he was there, and when I came up he was gone with it. I went after him, and took him just by. He gave it me out of his pocket.

JOHN GRIFFITHS
. I am surveyor of the roads. I was near the prosecutor's premises. He gave an alarm that the prisoner had robbed him. I followed, and brought him back. I asked how he came to rob a poor seaman. He said the devil tempted him.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 31.
Fined One Shilling and Discharged.

1301.
MARY THON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of July , a shirt, value 2 s.; a petticoat, value 1 s.; a bonnet, value 5 s., and a frock, value 6 d., the goods of
Michael Deady
; and three caps, value 1 s. the goods of
Ellen Connel
.

MICHAEL DEADY
. I am a labourer , and live in Calmell-buildings
. On the 24th of July I got up to go to work. Between five and six o'clock I went down to open my bed-room door, to call my fellow-labourer. I opened the door, and met the prisoner coming out. She turned to go down stairs. I stopped her, and asked what brought her there. All this property was in the room. I said she should not go unless she said what brought her into my room. I found three boxes turned over, and property taken out. The things in question, which were safe overnight, were packed up, to be taken away. My fellow-labourer was fast asleep in the room. She said a woman in the street had sent her. Three caps of Connell's, who lodges with me, were found in her pocket.

HENRY STEEL
. I am an officer. I went to the house, and found her there. She would not say a word. The property was tied up in a bundle.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I met one Murphy, who said she lodged in this house, but owed a little money, and they would not let her have her things, and sent me for them.
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Transported for Seven Years .
